answers.author: Alexandra Iannolo
answers.text:
Hello,
I found some sample social media policies that discuss balancing personal and private use of Facebook as a public employee.
Albemarle County, VA.
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/301489
 City of Winchester, Section 9 B and C
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/105220/The_City_of_Winchesters_Social_Media_Policy
Orange County, CA, Section 4 and 7
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/301300/Orange_Countys_Social_Media_Policy_and_Guidelines
City of Arlington, TX, Section 7
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/105221/The_City_of_Arlingtons_Social_Media_Policy_and_Social_Media_Definitions
 Palm Beach County, FL
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/302923/Social_Networking_PolicyPalm_Beach_County_FL
City of Suwanee
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/9166/Suwanees_Employee_Internet_and_Social_Media_Posting
I also included an article called, Social Media Strategy and Implementation which discusses best practices for creating social media policy and case studies.
http://icma.org/en/Article/100259/Social_Media_Strategy_and_Implementation
Ali Iannolo
Knowledge Network Intern
aiannolo@ICMA.org

author: Penny Burciaga
text: For instance, if county govt. wants employees logging in to county and dept. Facebook, etc. do the employees create a "professional" or "employee acct" in which to engage with co-workers and the public?  If they are logging in with their personal accounts then their personal info is there for everyone to see.  According to Facebook's ULA - a person can not have more than 1 acct. although many people do.  I'm very interested in knowing how others are handling this issue.  Thanks for the info everyone!
title: How to handle personal vs. professional social media accounts?
